newsitem.title: BELGIUM: American paper producers seek faster tariff cuts.
newsitem.headline: American paper producers seek faster tariff cuts.

text.p: North American paper producers, complaining they are at a competitive disadvantage compared with their European rivals, are pressing for action to speed up the elimination of tariffs on newsprint and other paper products.

The American Forest & Paper Association (AF&PA) and the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association are pushing for action to accelerate tariff cuts at the first ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation in Singapore on December 9-13.
"We want to see effort made to advance the demise of the paper tariffs that are in the Uruguay Round, to have them end on January 1, 1998," AF&PA president Henson Moore told reporters on Thursday.
This would be six years earlier than was agreed in the Uruguay Round trade pact in 1994.
The AF&PA says that European tariffs on paper products are much higher than in the United States, Canada or Japan.
"It is an irritant...the idea is to create a level playing field in international trade," Moore said.

An EU official said Europe favoured further tariff cuts across the board but that any product must be taken in the context of a balanced package. He noted that the United States for example had high textiles tariffs.
The Singapore conference is expected to review the Uruguay Round and set the pace for new trade talks due to begin in 1999.
"Singapore probably won't have a tariff cutting package. It might allude to a tariff cutting package in the future," the EU official told Reuters.
Moore, participating in the general assembly meeting of the Confederation of European Paper Industries in Brussels, said the Canadian government had proposed faster elimination of tariffs.
"We have the belief that our government is going to support it very strongly," he said.
"This needs to be finished off. We see no value in those tariffs, no need for them except it gives an unfair competitive advantage," he added.
According to AF&PA, some European tariffs are still at seven percent while most paper products enter the United States duty free. This has caused rising European paper exports to the United States.
In 1995, AF&PA said, EU producers shipped 2.2 million tonnes worth $2.5 billion to the North American market.

In a statement it said tariff cuts would "directly benfit paper users, such as newspapers and magazine publishers, commercial printers and the packaging industry. Acclerating the cuts will provide these benefits sooner."
